episodeTitle: I Will Make it Bloom! Usopp the Man and the Eight-Foot Shell!
episodeTitleJapanese: 咲かせてみせます！男ウソップ八尺玉
episodeTitleRomanized: Sakasete Misemasu! Otoko Usoppu Hasshaku Dama
description: The Straw Hat Pirates arrive at Fireworks Island during its annual 400-year-old fireworks festival. Usopp seeks gunpowder for the ship and meets Kodama, a young pyrotechnician whose parents died trying to launch a massive firework called Ball 205. With Usopp's ingenuity and encouragement, Kodama and her grandfather Odama successfully launch the legendary firework, honoring her parents' dream while teaching Kodama that she herself is their greatest legacy.

events.title: Straw Hats Arrive at Fireworks Island
events.description: The Straw Hat Pirates dock at Fireworks Island during preparations for its annual fireworks festival. The island is bustling with locals preparing for the 400-year-old tradition, and the crew learns about the festival's rich history.
events.significance: Sets the stage for Usopp's character-focused adventure and introduces the island's cultural significance.

events.title: Usopp Seeks Gunpowder
events.description: Usopp realizes the crew needs gunpowder for their journey and decides to seek it from the island's master pyrotechnician who lives atop the mountain. This practical need becomes the catalyst for the episode's story.
events.significance: Demonstrates Usopp's role as the crew's craftsman and weapons specialist, while setting up his meeting with Odama and Kodama.

events.title: Odama's Debut
events.description: Usopp reaches the mountaintop workshop and meets Odama, a stern elderly pyrotechnician with a stoic personality. Odama immediately dismisses Usopp as a 'novice firework maker' and refuses to help him, especially on the busy festival day.
events.significance: Introduces Odama as a skilled but abrasive craftsman who guards his family's pyrotechnic traditions fiercely.

quotes.text: I have no time for a novice firework maker like you, especially on the day of the festival!
quotes.speaker: Odama

events.title: Kodama's Debut
events.description: Kodama, Odama's enthusiastic young granddaughter, arrives at the workshop and meets Usopp. She inspects his handmade firework and compliments his craftsmanship, showing genuine appreciation for his skills where her grandfather saw only mediocrity.
events.significance: Introduces Kodama as a passionate young pyrotechnician who represents the next generation carrying on the family tradition.

events.title: Ball 205 Firework Revealed
events.description: Kodama shows Usopp the Ball 205, an enormous 200-gauge firework shell that dwarfs anything Usopp has seen. The massive firework represents the pinnacle of their family's pyrotechnic art, requiring special equipment and techniques to launch safely.
events.significance: Establishes the central object of the episode's plot and showcases the scale of the family's ambitions and lost traditions.

events.title: Tragic Death of Kodama's Parents
events.description: Kodama reveals that one year ago, her parents attempted to launch a Ball 205 firework but the launch equipment was flawed. The accident resulted in both of their deaths, leaving Kodama orphaned and in her grandfather's care. Their family once possessed the skills to safely launch 200-gauge shells, but this knowledge was lost over generations.
events.significance: Provides emotional weight to the episode and establishes the danger and importance of reviving the lost technique. Shows how traditions can be lost and the risks involved in trying to reclaim them.

quotes.text: A year ago, they tried to fire a similarly huge firework, but the equipment was flawed and there was an accident which killed both of my parents.
quotes.speaker: Kodama
quotes.context: Kodama explaining the tragedy that befell her family

events.title: Kodama's Dangerous Plan
events.description: Kodama confides in Usopp her secret plan to launch the Ball 205 during the festival if weather permits. She assures him that while the launch team will help set up the firework, she alone will ignite it to ensure everyone else's safety, willing to risk her own life to honor her parents' dream.
events.significance: Reveals Kodama's determination and recklessness, setting up the conflict between honoring her parents and ensuring her own safety.

quotes.text: If the weather allows it, I plan on launching the huge firework at the night of the festival. I will fire it up by myself so everyone else will be safe.
quotes.speaker: Kodama
quotes.context: Kodama revealing her dangerous plan to Usopp

events.title: Odama Forbids the Launch
events.description: After learning about Kodama's plan from the launch team, Odama confronts his granddaughter and strictly forbids her from attempting to launch the Ball 205. His harsh reaction stems from fear of losing Kodama the same way he lost her parents, though his stern demeanor masks his deep concern.
events.significance: Creates the central conflict between safety and ambition, between protecting loved ones and honoring the past.

events.title: Kodama Runs Away
events.description: After her grandfather's prohibition and harsh words, Kodama runs away from the workshop in tears. She heads to the cemetery where her parents are buried, seeking solace and connection with their memory.
events.significance: Shows Kodama's emotional turmoil and sets up Usopp's pivotal conversation with her.

events.title: Usopp's Wisdom at the Cemetery
events.description: Usopp finds Kodama at her parents' graves and helps her understand the true meaning of their dream. He explains that their parents' dream wasn't just about launching the Ball 205, but about her - that she would carry on the family tradition and become a master pyrotechnist. He makes her realize that she is the embodiment of their dream, not the firework.
events.significance: A pivotal character moment showing Usopp's maturity and wisdom. Despite his usual cowardice and boasting, he demonstrates deep emotional intelligence and understanding of what truly matters in life - people over accomplishments.

quotes.text: Your parents' dream is not just about launching a 200-gauge shell. You are their dream. Their dream is that you carry on the family tradition and become a master pyrotechnist.
quotes.speaker: Usopp
quotes.context: Usopp helping Kodama understand her parents' true wishes

events.title: Usopp's Pulley System Solution
events.description: Usopp devises an ingenious pulley system to safely transport and launch the massive Ball 205 firework. His engineering solution solves the technical problem that caused the fatal accident, allowing the firework to be launched without risking lives.
events.significance: Demonstrates Usopp's technical genius and problem-solving abilities. Shows how his skills as an inventor and craftsman can help others achieve their dreams safely.

events.title: Discovery of the Ancient Launch Platform
events.description: It is revealed that the tower in Odama's workshop is actually a 400-year-old launch platform specifically designed for launching 200-gauge shells. This ancient structure represents the family's long history and the traditional methods that were forgotten over time.
events.significance: Connects the present to the past, showing that the solution to their problem existed all along in their heritage. Represents the importance of preserving and understanding traditional knowledge.

events.title: Successful Launch of Ball 205
events.description: Using Usopp's pulley system and the ancient launch platform, Usopp and Odama successfully launch the massive Ball 205 firework into the night sky. The 200-gauge shell explodes in a spectacular display of white falling stars, fulfilling Kodama's parents' dream and honoring the 400-year tradition.
events.significance: The climactic moment that brings together past and present, tradition and innovation. Shows how respecting heritage while embracing new ideas can achieve what seemed impossible. Honors the memory of Kodama's parents while ensuring her future.

events.title: Odama Gives Usopp Gunpowder
events.description: After witnessing Usopp's skill and character, Odama relents and provides the gunpowder the Straw Hats need for their journey. Despite his initial reservations about helping pirates, he recognizes Usopp's genuine craftsmanship and good intentions.
events.significance: Completes Usopp's original mission while showing how earning respect through skill and character transcends initial prejudices.

themes.description: The episode explores how traditions are passed down through generations and the importance of preserving cultural heritage. Kodama's family has maintained their firework-making tradition for 400 years, but knowledge was lost over time, leading to tragedy.
themes.symbolism: The ancient launch platform represents forgotten wisdom and the importance of understanding one's heritage. The Ball 205 symbolizes both the burden and honor of carrying on family traditions.
culturalReferences: The concept of family trades passed through generations

themes.description: Usopp helps Kodama understand that her parents' true dream wasn't the firework itself, but her future as a master pyrotechnician. The episode contrasts tangible goals with the deeper aspirations parents have for their children.
themes.symbolism: The firework represents visible accomplishments, while Kodama herself represents the intangible but more important dream of continuing the family legacy safely.

themes.description: The episode shows how new ideas (Usopp's pulley system) and old wisdom (the ancient launch platform) can work together. Progress doesn't mean abandoning tradition, but rather understanding and respecting it while finding safer, better methods.
themes.symbolism: Usopp's modern engineering combined with the 400-year-old platform represents the harmony between innovation and tradition.

themes.description: Kodama struggles with her parents' death and the conflict between honoring their memory and ensuring her own safety. The episode shows how grief can drive people to dangerous decisions, but also how understanding the true wishes of lost loved ones can provide healthy closure.
themes.symbolism: The cemetery scene represents confronting grief, while the successful launch represents healthy remembrance that honors the dead without risking the living.

themes.description: The episode highlights Usopp's skills as an inventor and craftsman, showing how technical expertise can bridge gaps between people. Both Usopp and Odama are proud craftsmen who initially clash but ultimately find common ground in their shared appreciation for skill and dedication.
themes.symbolism: The fireworks themselves represent the beauty that can be created through dedication to one's craft.
culturalReferences: Japanese artisan culture and the concept of shokunin (craftsman) spirit

characterSpotlights.development: This episode showcases Usopp's often-overlooked qualities: his technical genius, emotional intelligence, and ability to inspire others. While he's usually portrayed as cowardly and boastful, here he demonstrates genuine wisdom and compassion, helping a grieving child find meaning beyond accomplishment.

characterSpotlights.development: Kodama begins the episode fixated on accomplishing what her parents couldn't, willing to risk her life to launch the Ball 205. Through Usopp's guidance, she learns that being alive and continuing the tradition is more important than any single achievement. She matures from reckless determination to understanding what truly matters.

characterSpotlights.development: Odama is initially portrayed as stern and dismissive, but his harsh exterior masks deep love for his granddaughter and fear of losing her. He learns to trust others (Usopp) and finds a way to honor his family's tradition while keeping Kodama safe.

mangaDifferences.difference: This episode is entirely anime-original filler content and does not appear in the manga. It was created during the Post-Arabasta filler arc to allow the manga to get further ahead.

trivia.fact: Episode 134 is part of the Post-Arabasta filler arc (Episodes 131-135), which is considered one of the best filler arcs in One Piece due to its character-focused stories and introspective tone.
The episode aired on November 24, 2002, with a TV rating of 12.8%, ranking 4th in viewership for its timeslot.
This episode has an IMDB rating of 6.7/10, which is relatively low for One Piece episodes, likely due to its filler status.

The episode title '八尺玉' (Hasshaku Dama) refers to a traditional Japanese firework shell that is approximately 8 shaku (about 2.4 meters or 8 feet) in diameter, representing the largest traditional firework size in Japanese pyrotechnics.

Despite being filler, this episode showcases important aspects of Usopp's character that align with canon material: his technical skills, his role as the crew's craftsman, and his surprising emotional depth.

The 400-year fireworks tradition mentioned in the episode reflects real Japanese hanabi (fireworks) culture, where many firework-making families have maintained their craft for centuries, passing down secret techniques through generations.
Kodama was voiced by Kumiko Nishihara in Japanese and Alese Johnson in the English dub. Both voice actresses effectively portrayed the character's youth and emotional journey.
